item.title: Mark Rosewater's New Lorwyn Eclipsed Teaser Gives a Sneak Peek to Light and Shadow
item.content:encoded:
Mark Rosewater has released a sneak peek at the next Magic: The Gathering set. The new Lorwyn Eclipsed teaser has provided tiny snippets of information regarding the set's new cards, creature types, and gameplay mechanics. Here is what was revealed.

Like all prior glimpses behind the curtain, the Magic: The Gathering Lorwyn Eclipsed teaser was revealed through a post on Rosewater's Tumblr account. As is tradition with past sneak peeks, the teaser contains partial information, snippets of game text devoid of context, in four distinct batches. These are designed to give dedicated Magic players a small glimpse at how the new set may change the play dynamics at the table.

The first batch reads as follows:

  • A planeswalker that makes Kithkin creature tokens
  • Kindred reprints
  • Some counters in the set: charge, dream, flying, first strike, indestructible, and lifelink
  • Another card in the Thirst for ________ series
  • Another card that makes something a Coward
  • A card that tutors every turn
  • A new card that copies triggers
  • A keyword introduced in 2025 returns
  • A number of Lorwyn/Shadowmoor block mechanics have cameos
  • Some tokens in the set: 1/1 colorless Shapeshifter, 1/1 blue/black Faerie, 2/2 black and green Elf, 3/3 green Elk, and 3/4 green Treefolk

As per usual, some of this information is straightforward. A Planeswalker that makes Kithkin tokens isn't too wild, given the Kithkin are a major race in Lorwyn. The return of certain Lorwyn and Shadowmoor block mechanics is expected as well.

But there are some pleasant surprises. Various Kindred cards getting reprinted is sure to delight players who use any color in their decks. There are also some head-turning phrases. A new card that copies triggers is interesting since it can potentially lead to greater multi-card combos, and a returning keyword from 2025 could mean anything.

The second batch of the Lorwyn Eclipsed teaser focuses on rules text. For those interested in how this set may shift the meta, this is where a lot of speculation lies. The batch reads as follows:

  • “As this artifact enters, choose Elemental, Elf, Faerie, Giant, Goblin, Kithkin, Merfolk, or Treefolk.”
  • “where X is the difference between its power and toughness.”
  • “Counter all spells your opponents control”
  • “Spend only to cast spells with a mana value 4 or greater.”
  • “If this is the third time this ability has resolved this turn,”
  • “This creature enters with six -1/-1 counters.”
  • “At the beginning of each end step, if you put a counter on a creature this turn,”
  • "You may cast that card without paying its mana cost if the spell’s mana value is less than or equal to the amount of life you gained this turn.”
  • “Add X {G} or X {W} where X is the number of other creatures you control.”
  • “Double all damage that sources you control of the chosen type would deal.”

As expected, the rules text covers many different playstyles. Control decks will enjoy just countering all enemy spells. Those who enjoy high-cost cards may enjoy a resource for cards costing four or more. And there is some mechanics around tokens for those who like engines that ramp up.

Some rules do stand out. Doubling all damage a chosen type deals can potentially lead to novel twists on burn playstyles, and a card that can be played for free based on life gain could mean a new focus on White spells and life gain.

The third and final batches of the Lorwyn Eclipsed teaser focus on creature types and card names in the set. Those batches read as follows:

  • Creature – Kithkin Ranger
  • Creature – Elemental Scout
  • Creature – Faerie Assassin
  • Creature – Noggle Rogue
  • Creature – Goblin Sorcerer
  • Creature – Ouphe
  • Creature – Giant Mercenary
  • Creature – Treefolk Cleric
  • Creature – Horse Serpent
  • Legendary Creature – Elf Faerie Noble
  • Bark of Doran
  • Champions of the Perfect
  • Chaos Spewer
  • Flitterwing Nuisance
  • Gilt-Leaf’s Embrace
  • Glister Bairn
  • Mirrorform
  • Moonglove Extractor
  • Moonshadow
  • Scuzzback Scrounger

Generally, this batch is full of expected terms for Lorwyn Eclipsed. It is a faerie-coded set, so much so it is now part of the Feywild in Dungeons & Dragons. As such, seeing Faerie Assassins, Elf Faerie Nobles, and Goblin Sorcerors are not surprising. As for the names, they do hold interesting connotations for the rules presented above.

Lorwyn Eclipsed is set to release worldwide on January 23, 2026.
